title: Wiener–Hopf method
summary: The Wiener–Hopf method is a mathematical technique widely used in applied mathematics. It was initially developed by Norbert Wiener and Eberhard Hopf as a method to solve systems of integral equations, but has found wider use in solving two-dimensional partial differential equations with mixed boundary conditions on the same boundary. In general, the method works by exploiting the complex-analytical properties of transformed functions.  Typically, the standard Fourier transform is used, but examples exist using other transforms, such as the Mellin transform.
